unnormalised: I remember when my grandmother, Savitri Devi, was diagnosed with Stage 3 ovarian cancer. It was back in 2018. Dr. Sharma at Tata Memorial Hospital in Mumbai, suggested a combination of chemotherapy and surgery. Initially, we were completely clueless about oncology and all its complexities. We heard about radiation therapy but weren't sure if it was needed in her case. They started her on a chemo regimen, something called "Paclitaxel + Carboplatin", I think. Each session cost about Rs. 15000.
normalised: I remember when my grandmother, Savitri Devi, was diagnosed with Stage three ovarian cancer. It was back in two thousand and eighteen. Doctor Sharma at Tata Memorial Hospital in Mumbai, suggested a combination of chemotherapy and surgery. Initially, we were completely clueless about oncology and all its complexities. We heard about radiation therapy but weren't sure if it was needed in her case. They started her on a chemo regimen, something called "Paclitaxel plus Carboplatin", I think. Each session cost about rupee fifteen thousand.

unnormalised: The whole process was draining. The side effects were terrible – nausea, hair loss, fatigue. But my grandmother, being the strong woman she was, never gave up. We used to travel from our village near Patna, Bihar to Mumbai every 3 weeks for her treatment. The doctors, especially Dr. Iyer, were so supportive. They explained everything patiently, including the option of palliative care if things didn't go as planned, although thankfully, that never became necessary. A PET scan on 04/05/2019 showed significant reduction in the tumour.

unnormalised: After the chemo, she underwent surgery to remove the remaining cancerous tissue. The surgery went well, and she was declared cancer-free in early 2020. Even now, she goes for regular check-ups every 6 months, including blood tests and CA-125 marker monitoring, to ensure the cancer hasn't returned. It's been a tough journey, but her resilience and the advancements in oncology have given her a new lease on life. I'm just grateful to God and the medical professionals who helped her along the way.
